title: 104_s598
content:
The Act titled "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on tobacco products. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on cigars and cigarettes. For cigars, the tax rate is amended to $5.8125 per thousand, and for large cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand, the tax is 65.875% of the price but not exceeding $155 per thousand. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on cigarettes, with rates amended to $62 per thousand for cigarettes and $130.20 per thousand for cigarette papers. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increased taxes on various tobacco products, including cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco. The tax rates were adjusted to 3.875 cents for cigarette tubes, 7.75 cents for snuff, $1.86 for smokeless tobacco, and 62 cents for chewing tobacco. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increased taxes on various tobacco products, including cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco. The tax rates were adjusted to $3.4875 for pipe tobacco, and the amendments apply to products removed after December 31, 1995. Additionally, a new excise tax on roll-your-own tobacco was imposed under section 5701 of the Internal Revenue Code. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increased taxes on various tobacco products, including roll-your-own tobacco, which now incurs a tax of $1.86 per pound. The definition of roll-your-own tobacco was also clarified to include tobacco suitable for making cigarettes. Technical amendments were made to section 5702 of the Internal Revenue Code. Technical amendments were made to section 5702 of the Internal Revenue Code, including the addition of "roll-your-own tobacco" alongside other tobacco products like cigars and cigarettes. The chapter heading for chapter 52 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include "roll-your-own tobacco" among other tobacco products like cigars and cigarettes for personal consumption or use. The chapter heading for chapter 52 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include "roll-your-own tobacco" among other tobacco products like cigars and cigarettes for personal consumption or use. The table of chapters for subtitle E of the Code is updated by replacing the item related to chapter 52 with a new item. The effective date for the amendments regarding roll-your-own tobacco and tobacco products is after December 31, 1995. A transitional rule applies to manufacturers and importers who submit an application before January 1, 1996. (c) Floor Stocks.-- On cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco manufactured in or imported into the United States which is removed before January 1, 1996, and held on such date, a transitional rule allows businesses to continue operations pending final action on their application under subchapter B of chapter 52 of the Code. All provisions of chapter 52 apply to the applicant as if they were a permit holder. For tobacco products removed before January 1, 1996, and held for sale, the following taxes are imposed: 
(A) Small cigars: $4.6875 per thousand for cigars weighing not more than 3 pounds per thousand. 
(B) Large cigars: 53.125% of the price for which sold, not exceeding $125 per thousand for cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand. 
(C) Small cigarettes: $50 per thousand for cigarettes weighing not more than 3 pounds per thousand. 
(D) Large cigarettes: $105 per thousand for cigarettes weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand, except those over 6.5 inches in length. On cigarette papers, the tax is 3.125 cents for each 50 papers or fraction thereof, with an exception for papers over 6.5 inches in length. Cigarette tubes are taxed at 6.25 cents for each 50 tubes or fraction thereof. (F) Cigarette tubes are taxed at 6.25 cents for each 50 tubes or fraction thereof, with an exception for tubes over 6.5 inches in length. Snuff is taxed at $1.50 per pound, chewing tobacco at 50 cents per pound, and pipe tobacco at $2.8125 per pound. Pipe tobacco is taxed at $2.8125 per pound with a proportionate tax on fractional parts. Those holding pipe tobacco on January 1, 1996, are liable for the tax, due on February 15, 1996, following the same payment method as other tobacco products. The tax on cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco removed on January 1, 1996, follows the definitions provided in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Retail stocks are exempt from these taxes. The taxes on cigars, cigarettes, and other tobacco products are based on the definitions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Retail stocks of these products held on January 1, 1996, are exempt from these taxes. Additionally, products in foreign trade zones are subject to specific regulations. Products subject to customs regulations include items like cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco. These products must be supervised by a customs officer before January 1, 1996, and if entered into the US from a foreign trade zone after that date. The Act of June 18, 1934 states that tobacco products entering the US from a foreign trade zone after January 1, 1996, are subject to tax and treated as being held for sale on that date. Additionally, a Trust Fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code for this purpose. The Act of June 18, 1934 establishes a Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund under the Internal Revenue Code for tobacco products entering the US from foreign trade zones after January 1, 1996. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund is created in the Treasury, funded by 3% of revenue increases from tobacco amendments, and available for Agriculture Secretary expenditures. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund, funded by 3% of revenue increases from tobacco amendments, is available for the Agriculture Secretary to provide assistance to farmers transitioning from tobacco to other crops, supporting economic diversification plans for communities and individuals involved in tobacco production. This assistance may include government purchase of tobacco allotments for those looking to exit tobacco production. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund, funded by 3% of revenue increases from tobacco amendments, provides assistance to farmers transitioning from tobacco to other crops, including government purchase of tobacco allotments for those exiting tobacco production. Additionally, there is a clerical amendment to the table of sections for subchapter A. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund, funded by 3% of revenue increases from tobacco amendments, assists farmers transitioning from tobacco to other crops.
